Title: Proving property of Fibonacci sequence with group theory
Content:
I stumbled upon this problem on a chapter about group theory, and I can't seem to get a grasp on it: Let $p$ be a prime and $F_1 = F 
_2 = 1, F_{n +2} = F_{n +1} + F_n$ be the Fibonacci sequence. Show that $F_{2p(p^2−1)}$ is divisible by $p$. The book gives the following hint: Look at the group of $2×2$ matrices mod $p$ with determinant $± 1$ I know I have to use lagrange theorem at some point, but how do I stablish the link between the fibonacci sequence and the matrices? I mean, I know that there's a special $2×2$ matrix such that it yields the $n^{th}$ fibonacci number when taking the $n^{th}$ power, I even used it to obtain a general formula for the numbers during my linear algebra course, but how can I use that to prove this?
AcceptedAnswer:
Call the group $G = \left\{A \in (\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{2\times 2} \ \middle\vert\ \det A = \pm 1\right\}$. First, we count the order of $G$. We have elements $\left(\array{a & b \\ c & d}\right)$, with $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ and $ad - bc \equiv \pm 1$ ($\equiv$ means congruent modulo $p$).
Let us first count the elements with determinant one. $\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ is a field, which means that every element except $0$ has a multiplicative inverse. Therefore, $ad - bc \equiv 1$ is equivalent to $(d \equiv 0\ \land\ c \equiv -b^{-1})\ \lor\ (a \not\equiv 0 \land d \equiv a^{-1}(1 + bc))$. Counting the possibilities gives
$$ \underbrace{(d \equiv 0\ \land\ c \equiv -b^{-1})}_{\text{$a$: $p$ choices, $b$: $p - 1$ choices}}\ \lor\ \underbrace{(a \not\equiv 0 \land d \equiv a^{-1}(1 + bc))}_{\text{$a$: $p - 1$ choices, $b,c$: $p$ choices}} $$
for a total of $p(p-1) + (p-1)p^2 = p(p+1)(p-1) = p(p^2 - 1)$ elements with determinant $1$.
By symmetry (swapping $a$ with $b$ and $d$ with $c$) there has to be an equal number of elements with determinant $-1$. So the order of $G$ is $|G| = 2p(p^2 - 1)$. Now, let $M = \left(\array{1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0}\right)$. You already know that $M^n = \left(\array{F_{n+1} & F_{n} \\ F_{n} & F_{n-1}}\right)$. For $M$, as for any element in a finite group, we know that $M^{|G|} = I$ (consider the cyclic subgroup $\left<M\right>$ generated by $M$ and use Lagrange's theorem). This fact translates to
$$ \left(\array{F_{2p(p^2 - 1) + 1} & F_{2p(p^2 - 1)} \\ F_{2p(p^2 - 1)} & F_{2p(p^2 - 1) - 1}}\right) \equiv \left(\array{1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1}\right) \mod{p}.$$
The off-diagonal components of this equation are what you wanted to show.

The Fibonacci sequence can be represented by the matrix [[1,1],[1,0]]. When you raise this matrix to the nth power, the top left entry is F_{n+1}, right? So, maybe if we consider this matrix modulo p, we can link the Fibonacci numbers modulo p to the order of this matrix in the group mentioned.

The group in question is the set of 2x2 matrices mod p with determinant ±1. Since p is prime, the determinant being ±1 mod p means those matrices are invertible, so they form a group under multiplication. The order of this group... Let me think. The general linear group GL(2,p) has order (p² -1)(p² - p). But here we have a subgroup where determinant is ±1. So, the determinant homomorphism maps to the multiplicative group mod p, which has order p-1. The kernel of determinant being ±1 would have size equal to the order of GL(2,p) divided by the size of the image. But the image here is the set {1, -1} mod p, assuming p ≠ 2. Wait, but determinant is allowed to be ±1, so the image is the subgroup {1, -1} in the multiplicative group. The multiplicative group mod p has order p-1, so the subgroup {1, -1} has order 2 if p is odd. So, the order of our group would be |GL(2,p)| / ( (p-1)/2 ). Wait, no. The determinant is a surjective homomorphism from GL(2,p) to the multiplicative group (which has order p-1). The group we're considering is the preimage of {1, -1} under det. So by the first isomorphism theorem, the order is |GL(2,p)| / ( (p-1)/2 )? Wait, no. The image here has size 2 (if p is odd), so the order of the subgroup would be |GL(2,p)| / ( (p-1)/2 ) )? Wait, maybe not. Let me check.

The order of GL(2,p) is (p² -1)(p² - p). The determinant is a surjective map to GF(p)^*, which has order p-1. So, the kernel of the determinant map is SL(2,p), which has order (p² -1)(p² - p)/ (p-1) ) = (p² -1)p. But in our case, the group is matrices with determinant ±1. So, that's the preimage of the subgroup {1, -1} of GF(p)^*. So, the order should be [SL(2,p)] multiplied by the size of the subgroup {1, -1}. Since the determinant is surjective, the preimage of a subgroup of size k has order |SL(2,p)| * k. Since {1, -1} has size 2 when p is odd, the order of our group would be |SL(2,p)| * 2 = 2p(p² -1). Wait, SL(2,p) has order p(p² -1). So, multiplying by 2 gives 2p(p² -1). Therefore, the group in the hint has order 2p(p² -1). 

By Lagrange's theorem, the order of any element in this group divides the group order. So, if we can show that the matrix [[1,1],[1,0]] has an order dividing 2p(p² -1), then its 2p(p² -1)th power would be the identity matrix modulo p. Then, looking at the top-left entry, which relates to F_{2p(p² -1) +1}, but maybe there's a shift here. Wait, the matrix power relation is:

[[1,1],[1,0]]^n = [[F_{n+1}, F_n],[F_n, F_{n-1}]]

So, if we raise this matrix to the kth power modulo p and get the identity matrix, then the top-left entry would be F_{k+1} ≡ 1 mod p, and the entry below it would be F_k ≡ 0 mod p. Wait, but if the entire matrix is identity, then F_{k+1} ≡ 1 mod p, F_k ≡ 0 mod p, F_{k} ≡ 0 mod p, and F_{k-1} ≡ 1 mod p. Wait, that seems conflicting unless k is such that F_k ≡ 0 mod p and F_{k+1} ≡ 1 mod p. Which is similar to the period of Fibonacci numbers modulo p, called the Pisano period. But perhaps the exponent 2p(p² -1) is a multiple of the Pisano period, hence F_{2p(p² -1)} ≡ 0 mod p.

But maybe instead of the Pisano period, we use the group theory approach. Since the matrix M = [[1,1],[1,0]] has determinant -1. Because det(M) = (1)(0) - (1)(1) = -1. So modulo p, the determinant is -1 mod p, so M is in the group of matrices with determinant ±1. Therefore, the order of M in this group divides the group order, which is 2p(p² -1). Therefore, M^{2p(p² -1)} ≡ I mod p. Therefore, the matrix raised to that power is the identity matrix. Therefore, looking at the entry, M^{2p(p² -1)} = [[F_{2p(p² -1)+1}, F_{2p(p² -1)}], [F_{2p(p² -1)}, F_{2p(p² -1)-1}]] ≡ [[1,0],[0,1]] mod p. Therefore, F_{2p(p² -1)} ≡ 0 mod p. Therefore, p divides F_{2p(p² -1)}. That seems to be the link. So the key idea is that the matrix M is in the group, its order divides the group order, so when raised to that exponent, it's identity, so the corresponding Fibonacci number is 0 mod p. So the problem is essentially applying Lagrange's theorem to the matrix group, leading to the conclusion.

But let me verify the steps again. The group has order 2p(p² -1). The matrix M is in the group because determinant is -1. Therefore, M raised to the order of the group is identity. So, M^{2p(p² -1)} ≡ I mod p. Therefore, the (1,2) entry, which is F_{2p(p² -1)}, must be congruent to 0 mod p, and the (1,1) entry is F_{2p(p² -1)+1} ≡ 1 mod p. Therefore, this shows that F_{2p(p² -1)} ≡ 0 mod p, hence divisible by p.
